Such precautions, established under customary international law, are as follows: (a) any belligerent party shall do all it can to ensure that the intended targets are not of a civilian nature; (b) take all possible precautions in the choice of means and methods of combat to prevent or at least reduce as much as possible the number of injuries that may incidentally be caused by the civilian population, as well as damage to civilian objects; (c) refrain from deciding on an attack when it is expected to cause incidental death or injury to the civilian population, damage to civilian objects, or both, which would be excessive in relation to the specific and direct military advantage envisaged; (d) give adequate advance notice and effective means of any attack that may affect the civilian population, except in the case of a live attack (as provided for in article 26 of the Hague Regulations of 1907) or, as provided for in article 57, paragraph 2 (c), unless circumstances prevent it, i.e. where one of the belligerent parties considers that a surprise attack is indispensable.
